title: الاسْتِثْنَاءُ بِـ عَدَا وَخَلَا وَحَاشَا
description: Learn about the exception particles عدا، خلا، and حاشا - their dual nature as verbs or prepositions, and how the المستثنى is parsed with each usage.

notes.title: Introduction to عدا، خلا، حاشا
content: عَدَا، خَلَا، and حَاشَا are exception words that mean 'except.' Unlike إِلَّا, these words have a dual grammatical nature: they can function either as verbs or as prepositions.
This duality affects the grammatical case of the المُسْتَثْنَى (excepted noun). When treated as verbs, the المستثنى is مَنْصُوب (object). When treated as prepositions, it is مَجْرُور.
keyPoints: Three exception words: عدا، خلا، حاشا

examples.arabic: جَاءَ الْقَوْمُ عَدَا زَيْدًا / عَدَا زَيْدٍ
قَامَ الطُّلَّابُ خَلَا مُحَمَّدًا / خَلَا مُحَمَّدٍ

notes.title: As Verbs (فِعْلِيَّة)
content: When عَدَا، خَلَا، and حَاشَا are treated as verbs, they are past tense verbs meaning 'to pass beyond' or 'to leave out.' The المُسْتَثْنَى becomes their مَفْعُول بِهِ (direct object) and takes نَصْب.
The فَاعِل (subject) of these verbs is a hidden pronoun (ضَمِير مُسْتَتِر) referring to an unspecified doer, often interpreted as 'some matter' or 'the situation.'

examples.english: They ate the food except the meat

notes.title: As Prepositions (حُرُوف جَرّ)
content: When treated as prepositions (حُرُوف جَرّ), عَدَا، خَلَا، and حَاشَا give the المُسْتَثْنَى the genitive case (جَرّ). This is the more common usage in everyday Arabic.
As prepositions, they function similarly to other exception prepositions, with the noun following them being مَجْرُور.

examples.english: I read the books except one book
He loved them except the liar
They visited the cities except one city

notes.title: With ما المصدرية
content: When مَا المصدرية precedes عَدَا or خَلَا (ما عدا، ما خلا), they MUST be treated as verbs. The مَا converts the following clause into a مَصْدَر مُؤَوَّل.
In this case, the المُسْتَثْنَى is obligatorily مَنْصُوب as the مَفْعُول بِهِ of the verb. This is the most common pattern in formal Arabic.
keyPoints: ما المصدرية makes them verbs only

examples.english: Students passed except one (must be acc)

examples.arabic: قَرَأْتُ كُلَّ شَيْءٍ مَا خَلَا الرِّوَايَاتِ

notes.title: حاشا in Detail
content: حَاشَا is used exclusively for rational beings (عَاقِل) and often carries a sense of exoneration or exclusion from blame. It appears frequently in Quranic usage.
Some grammarians consider حَاشَا to be primarily a preposition, while others allow both usages. It is rarely preceded by مَا.

examples.english: Allah forbid! This is no mortal (Quran 12:31)
All of them erred except the teacher
They accused them except the truthful ones
Far be it from him to lie

notes.title: Summary and Comparison
content: All three words (عَدَا، خَلَا، حَاشَا) allow both نَصْب and جَرّ for the المُسْتَثْنَى when used alone. With مَا المصدرية, only نَصْب is allowed.
Compare with إِلَّا which always requires the المُسْتَثْنَى to follow standard exception rules (usually نَصْب in complete affirmative sentences).

examples.arabic: مَا عَدَا زَيْدًا ✓ / مَا عَدَا زَيْدٍ ✗

examples.english: They came except Zayd (all three work)

exercises.prompt: عَدَا وَخَلَا وَحَاشَا تَكُونُ أَفْعَالًا أَوْ _____ جَرٍّ
exercises.promptEn: عدا، خلا، and حاشا can be verbs or _____ of jarr

exercises.prompt: إِذَا كَانَتْ عَدَا فِعْلًا، فَالْمُسْتَثْنَى يَكُونُ _____
exercises.promptEn: If عدا is a verb, the المستثنى is _____

exercises.prompt: إِذَا سَبَقَتْ مَا الْمَصْدَرِيَّةُ عَدَا، فَالْمُسْتَثْنَى _____ فَقَطْ
exercises.promptEn: If ما المصدرية precedes عدا, the المستثنى is _____ only

exercises.prompt: حَضَرَ الْجَمِيعُ خَلَا _____ / أَحْمَدًا (both valid without ما)

exercises.answer: Except (verb or preposition meaning to pass beyond)
Except (ما makes عدا obligatorily a verb)
Allah forbid! / Far be it from Allah (exoneration expression)

exercises.prompt: Except/other than (can be verb or preposition)
Far be it from (used for exoneration)
